loans.name: Gorgui

texts.fr: Gorgui est un homme marié et père de huit enfants. Depuis plus de 40 ans, il pratique l'agriculture et l'élevage.Il cultive des champs de mil et d'arachide.Il achète également des boeufs qu'il engraisse puis revend.Il entretient sa famille avec les revenus tirés de ces deux activités. Aujourd'hui, il sollicite un pret de 250000f pour acheter un bœuf et des aliments de bétail.Il ambitionne de réaliser un grand enclos pour mieux pratiquer l'embouche bovine.
texts.en:
Gorgui is a married man and a father of eight children. For over forty years, he has been a farmer and has raised livestock. He has fields of millet and peanuts. He also buys cattle and fattens them and then resells them. He takes care of his family with the revenues derived from these two businesses. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of 250,000 francs to buy a head of cattle and some animal feed. His ambition is to build a large pen to raise cattle better.

loans.use: to buy cattle and some animal feed

loans.name: Vincent

texts.fr:
Vincent est né au Rwanda et il a 28 ans, il est marie avec 1 enfant de 1an. Son niveau d’éducation est de 5 ans de secondaire.
Vincent est commerçant. C’est son premier  cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter 20 sacs de ciment, 8 pièces de triplex, 2 camions de sable, 3 portes pour construire sa maison d’habitation.

Dans les prochaines années, il voudrait  construire des maisons destine à louer.
texts.en:
Vincent was born in Rwanda and is 28 years old. He is married and has one child, who is 1 year old. Vincent has five years of secondary education. He is a merchant. 

This loan cycle is his first one with the microfinance institution ACB. He is going to use his loan to buy 20 sacks of cement, 8 pieces of triplex, 2 truckloads of sand, and 3 doors to build his house. 

In the coming years, he would like to build a house to rent out.

loans.use: to buy 20 sacks of cement, 8 each of triplex, 2 truckloads of sand, and 3 doors to build house

loans.name: Milton

texts.en:
Milton is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala East region of Uganda. He is married and has one child. For the past three years, Milton has been working hard to manage his poultry farm which sells chicken. 

To help expand his business, Milton has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more chickens for resale and will help Milton to generate greater profits and manage to set up more chicken houses. Milton hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his farm and to also start keeping cattle. 

Milton is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small business owners like Milton who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more chickens for resale

loans.name: Jammiyatou Takhwoun 2 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe "Jammiyatou Takhwoun 2" est un groupe de solidarité qui se  compose de 5 hommes originaires de la région centre du pays.Ils exercent dans le commerce de produits céréaliers.Ils achètent de grandes quantités à l'intérieur du pays, les stockent puis les revendent lorsque la demande baisse sur les marchés.Cette activité leur permet d'entretenir leurs familles et de subvenir à leurs propres besoins.Le chef de groupe(en pantalon et chemise , à gauche) est un ancien étudiant qui a quitté l'université après deux ans pour se lancer dans le commerce.Il tient ainsi un magasin de vente d'arachide, de mil, de haricot, et d'autres produits agricoles.Il vend aussi de la paille d'arachide qui sert de nourriture aux moutons et bœufs mis en stabulation.Afin de renforcer leurs fonds de commerce, le groupe sollicite un pret de 500000f pour acheter des produits céréaliers.
texts.en:
The group "Jammiyatou Takhwoun 2" is a solidarity group composed of five men from the same central region of the country. They have commercial businesses involving grain products. They buy large quantities inland, stock them, and then resell them when the market demand is low. This business enables them to take care of their families and to support themselves. 

The head of the group (wearing pants and a shirt at the left in the photo) is a former student who left university after two years to get started in commerce. Thus he has a store selling peanuts, millet, beans, and other farm produce. He also sells peanut plant stalks used as food for sheep and cattle in stables. 

To bolster its business capital, the group is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs to buy grain products.

loans.use: to buy grain products

loans.name: Reyna Elizabeth

texts.es:
Reyna es una mujer de 27 años, se encuentra felizmente casada, vive en la ciudad de Nazca con su esposo y sus 2 pequeños hijos de 7 y 1 años de edad, ella siempre ha sido una persona muy trabajadora, entusiasta y emprendedora, que dedica todos sus esfuerzos junto con su esposo para sacara adelante a su familia; lamentablemente por la necesidad de trabajar y solventar sus gastos no pudo cursar una carrera profesional, pero le hubiera gustado mucho poder hacerlo; en sus ratos le gusta dedicar un poco de tiempo a la lectura y en algunas ocasiones cocina un riquísimo Arroz Chaufa para compartir con su familia.
Por iniciativa propia y gracias al apoyo de su familia, Reyna arrendo una pequeña parcela donde cultiva pallar, ella dedica a su negocio un aproximado de 10 horas diarias, donde desde tempranas horas de la mañana ella se dedica a realizar las labores de campo que requiere su cultivo; ella se siente a gusto realizando esta labor ya que desde niña sus padres le ensañaron este tipo de trabajos y ella desea seguir con esta tradición familiar.
Reyna se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestatarios Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá cubrir los gastos de fumigación con pesticidas, herbicidas y los gastos de riego que requiere su cultivo; de esta manera Reyna podrá mantener su cultivo en buenas condiciones y así cuando su cosecha termine podrá obtener buenas ganancias, con las cuales en un futuro no muy lejano espera poder comprar un terreno propio para sus futuros sembríos.
texts.en:
Reyna, 27, is happily married and lives with her husband and their 2 small children, 7 and 1, in Nazca.  She has always been a hard-working, enthusiastic and entrepreneurial woman who puts all her effort together with her husband to get the family ahead.  Sadly, because of the need to work and cover expenses, she couldn’t study to be a professional but she very much would have liked to have done so.  With her free time she likes to read and sometimes prepare a delicious  arroz Chaufa (Peruvian fried rice) to share with her family.

On her own initiative and thanks to the support of her family, Reynda rented a small piece of land where she grows butter beans.  She spends about  10 hours a  day starting very early in the morning with the farm work that needs to be done.  She is happy in this work since her parents taught her from when she was very young and she wants to continue with the family tradition.

Reyna is very grateful for the Kiva loans since thanks to them, she has been helped covering the costs of fumigation and the irrigation expenses that the plants need.  This way Reyna can keep her crop healthy and also when the plants are ready, she can get a good income.  In the near future she would like to buy her own land for future planting.

loans.use: to pay for fumigation and irrigation expenses and herbicides

loans.name: Nicolasa

texts.es: Nicolasa de 51 años de edad, vive al suroccidente de la ciudad con su cónyuge y tiene 3 hijos en las edades de 24 a 29 años, con los que sueña ver convertidos en personas de mucho éxito. Ella hace de todo un poco con el fin de generar ingresos para apoyar el bienestar de su hogar: por un lado se dedica a confeccionar ropa de dormitorios, y por otro a vender calzado a crédito entre clientes seleccionados, productos lácteos y carnes frías. Desde muy niña legó a la ciudad y trabajó en varios hogares de familia, posteriormente trabajó en talleres de confecciones como operaria  y al final decidió emprender su propia aventura de negocio, en tanto que su tiempo no le alcanzaba para proteger y velar por su familia. Por eso inició su negocio ofreciéndole a sus vecinas la mano de obra y siendo apoyada por su cónyuge, quien ha sido cotero de una empresa  importante por mucho tiempo. Poco a poco logró captar una clientela fija y ella empezó con sus propios recursos a invertir en materias primas e insumos y a desarrollar sus propias modas, así creció aun más y paso a paso ha ido agregando otros productos, como  calzado, lácteos y carnes frías, es decir siempre que se le presenta la posibilidad de ganar dinero, mediante la inversión segura, ella le apunta a eso, porque su fuerza de trabajo se lo permite y ella se exige a si misma cada vez mas.  En la actualidad su creciente clientela ha generado una mayor demanda de artículos, a los que ella no puede responder oportunamente como quisiera, porque debe esperar recuperar su dinero que en la actualidad está en manos de sus clientes. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace ala Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará telas, hilos, suero, calzado, artículos que forman parte de las exigencias de sus clientes en la preventa que ella continuamente realiza y que es lo que potencializa el éxito de sus inversiones.
texts.en: 51-year-old Nicolasa lives with her husband in the southwestern part of town. She has three children ranging in age from 24 to 29, and she dreams of seeing them become very successful people. She does a little of everything in order to get an income that supports the welfare of her household. On one hand, she makes bedlinen, and on the other hand she sells shoes on credit to selected customers as well as dairy products and cold cuts. Ever since she was very young, she arrived in town and worked in many family homes. Later on, she worked for dressmaker's workshops and then she finally decided to start her own business venture, because she didn't have enough time to protect and care for her family. For that reason she started her business by offering her labor to her neighbors. She had support from her husband, who has been a truck loader for an important company for a long time. She gradually succeeded in getting regular customers, and she started using her own resources to invest in supplies and develop her own designs. That way she kept growing and adding other merchandise little by little, such as shoes, dairy products and cold cuts. That is to say, anytime she's presented with the possibility to make money through sound investments, she's up for it, because her will to work allows it and she always demands more and more from herself. Currently, her growing clientele has resulted in more orders for merchandise. She can't meet them in a timely fashion as she would like to, because she has to wait to collect the money that's currently in the hands of her customers. That's the reason why she requests a Kiva loan, her first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. She will use it to purchase fabric, thread, whey and shoes. These items are part of what her customers demand in the pre-sales she continually makes, and that's what boosts the success of her investments.

loans.use: to purchase fabric, thread, whey and shoes.

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr: Madame Salimata habite au Sénégal. Elle est mariée et à sa charge deux enfants dont l’un est âgé de 12 ans et l’autre de 6 ans. Elle est femme de  ménage dans une cité de la place depuis plus de 10 ans. Elle  est membre dans   l’un des guichets de l’U-IMCEC et a déjà remboursé un prêt antérieur. Elle  sollicite un crédit de 75 000 fca  prévu pour le règlement des frais médicaux en vue d’assister sa maman qui est malade. Avec ce nouveau crédit sollicité. Son objectif est de rétablir l’équilibre social à la maison mais son projet futur consiste a devenir dans l’avenir une grande commerçante de produits diversifiés (tissus, chaussures et produits cosmétiques).
texts.en:
Ms. Salimata lives in Senegal. She is married and support two children, of whom one is 12 years old, and the other is 6. She has been a housekeeper in a local housing development for over ten years. 

She is a member of a U-IMCEC branch office and has already repaid a previous loan. She is requesting a loan of 75,000 francs for paying medical bills for the purposes of helping her mother, who is ill. 

With this new loan being requested, her goal is to restore the social balance in her home, and her future plans consist in becoming a major businesswoman of diverse goods (fabrics, shoes, and cosmetics).

loans.use: to pay for her mother's medical expenses

loans.name: Mildred

texts.es: Mildred de 49 años de edad,  vive al sur occidente de la ciudad con su familia conformada por su cónyuge y sus 4 hijos en las edades de 22 a 30 años. Ella tiene un negocio mediante el cual vende alimentos y otro mediante el cual distribuye mercancía variada mediante plazos especiales y al detalle. Estas actividades las combina muy bien,  así la venta de comidas está dirigida a empleados de empresas que están ubicadas alrededor de su vivienda, a quienes lleva diariamente almuerzos y/o meriendas,  pues ellos no pueden trasladarse a su vivienda a consumirlos,  también vende galletas exquisitas provenientes de su pueblo natal llamadas “Chepa-Corinas”, y por otro lado vende productos mediante catálogos o guías especializadas a través de los  cuales promociona cosméticos, perfumería, ropa etc. Su meta mas adelante,  es tener su propia casa  en el proyecto Sueños y Oportunidades, liderado por la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y empresarialmente continuar ampliando su pequeño punto de ventas. Esta última es la razón por la cual acude a un credikiva mediante el cual comprará mesas plásticas y sillas, para brindar un ambiente confortable a su clientela demandante, que no ha podio atender y también comprará mercancías variadas, como ropa que tiene encargada y va a dar respuesta a su clientela, siendo así cada vez mas oportuna con ellos.
texts.en:
Mildred is 49 years old. She lives south-west of the city with her family, which consists of her spouse and four children (between the ages of 22 and 30). She has one business where she sells food and another where she distributes a variety of retail goods during special periods of time.

These businesses serve her very well. The food sales are aimed at employees of businesses that are located near her home. Every day she takes them lunches and/or snacks because they can't come to her home to eat them. She also sells delicious cookies called “chepa-corinas” that come from her hometown. 

And on the other hand she sells products through catalogues that promote cosmetics, perfumes, clothing, etc.

Her goal for the future is to have her own home through the Sueños y Oportunidades (Dreams and Opportunities) project which is sponsored by the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.

As far as her business goes, she wants to continue increasing her small number of sales.

This last goal is the reason for which she is asking for a Kiva loan that she will use to buy plastic tables and chairs to provide a more comfortable atmosphere for her demanding customers that she hasn't been able to attend to.

She will also buy a variety of other merchandise like clothing that has been pre-ordered. She can then let her customers know and be more timely each time with them.

loans.use: to buy plastic tables and chairs and a variety of other merchandise that has been pre-ordered through catalogues.

loans.name: Benoït Coly

texts.fr: Benoït est un homme marié et père de quatre enfants. Il tient un commerce de denrées alimentaires dans une boutique implantée dans son quartier.Il vend en détail du riz, de l'huile, du sucre , du savon et d'autres divers produits de consommation courante.Ce commerce lui rapporte des revenus qui lui permettent de prendre en charge les besoins de sa famille ainsi que ses propres besoins.Afin de renforcer son fonds de commerce, il sollicite un pret de 500000f pour acheter du riz, de l'huile et du sucre.Son ambition est d'ouvrir une seconde boutique.
texts.en:
Benoït is a married man and the father of four children. He has a provisions business in a store set up in his district. He is a retail seller of rice, oil, sugar, soap, and a variety of other common consumer goods. This business brings in the revenues allowing him to take care of his family, as well as himself. 

To bolster his business capital, he is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs to buy rice, oil, and sugar. His ambition is to open another store.

loans.use: to buy rice, oil, and sugar

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy work tools

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy work tools

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy work tools

loans.name: Particia

texts.en:
Particia is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala east region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. For the past six years, Particia has been working hard to manage her restaurant which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Particia has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more fresh food like matooke (made from bananas) to cook for resale. This will help Particia to generate greater profits and to manage to keep her children at school. Particia hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business into a hotel. 

Particia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Particia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to stock fresh food like matooke to cook for resale

loans.name: Carlos Gilbel

texts.es:
Carlos, está solicitando un nuevo préstamo, porque iniciara el trabajo agrícola, para esto deberá comprarse los materiales como el abono y los herbicidas, que son muy necesarios para prevenir de las plagas al cultivo de maíz y frijol.
El préstamo anterior le ayudo a Carlos a comprarse los materiales para aplicarlos al cultivo, del cual logro tener una buena cosecha, de la que ha logrado tener disponibilidad para vender y para alimento familiar, tambien se compro dos terneros.
texts.en: Carlos is requesting a new loan to begin his agricultural work. He plans to purchase materials like fertilizer and herbicides, which are very necessary to prevent plagues to his corn and bean crops. The previous loan helped him buy materials to apply to his crops, through which he achieved a good harvest that he was able to sell and feed his family, and he also purchased two plots of land.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and herbicides.

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Florece

texts.en:
Florece is 39 years old and lives in the town of Gaba in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past 10 years, Florece has been working hard to run a nursery school. 

To help expand her business, Florece has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to increase the size of her school which will help Florece to generate greater profits and create more classrooms. Florece hopes that in the future she will be able to create a bigger school. 

Florece is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Florece who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to increase the size of her school

loans.name: Al-Nagah Group

texts.en:
This group is called Al-Nagah. The group is made up of 4 members: Najah, Hakimh, Sawod and Aml. They have applied for a loan of 190000 YER from AMB. They live in Sana`a, Yemen.

The president of the group, Najah, is 28-years-old and a single woman (she is the woman who holds beige dress). She makes a living by making ladies clothes. She started her business with sewing babies' clothes, then sewing dresses. She intends to expand her business to sew wedding dresses. She applied for a youth loan of 40000 YER from AMB. She is going to use this loan to buy wholesale fabric. Her reason for asking for the loan is that she lacks the cash. She faces challenges in her business. She is going to use the profits to continue buying machinery and materials for her business and thus, be able to generate more income.

loans.use: to buy wholesale fabric for her business.

loans.name: Ismail

texts.en:
Ismail is a married man and is 41 years old. He has six children in addition to one dependent.

Ismail repairs bicycles in the outskirts of Kabura-Kooki, a surburb in Lyantonde. He has been doing this since 2007 and has been able to build himself a house and educate his children. His main clients are the inhabitants of the area where he operates from, and they are predominantly carriers. Because bicycles are their main method of transportation while ferrying milk into town, Ismail has a ready market.

His main challenge is not having enough money to buy spare parts, which are rather expensive.

He hopes to start buying bicycles to sell if he gets enough money.

Ismail is a very hardworking man. In the photo is Ismail at his business, and the other people in the photo consented to have their picture taken.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for trade

loans.name: Hamidah

texts.en:
Hamidah is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale, in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children, with 2 of them currently in school. For the past 5 years, Hamidah has been working hard to manage her clothing business. 

To help expand her business, Hamidah has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more stock for her shop and will help Hamidah to generate greater profits and to increase daily sales. Hamidah hopes that, in the future, she will be able to open another branch in town. 

Hamidah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hamidah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her shop.

loans.name: Posiyano

texts.en:
Posiyano is 26 years old and lives in the town of Kireka, in the Kampala south region of Uganda. He is married and has 2 children, 1 of them currently in school. 

For the past 5 years, Posiyano has been working hard to manage his small business, which sells motor spare parts. To help expand his business, Posiyano has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more motor spare parts for resale, and will help Posiyano to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his child. Posiyano hopes that, in the future, he will be able to start a large motor spare parts shop  in town. 

Posiyano is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Posiyano who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more motor spare parts for resale.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward is 45 years old and lives in the town of Kireka, in the Kampala south region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, 2 of them currently in school. 

For the past 5 years, Edward has been working hard to manage his stone quarrying, which sells stones that are used for building houses. To help expand his business, Edward has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more materials to be used in the stone quarrying business, and will help Edward to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Edward hopes that, in the future, he will be able to own a hardware shop. 

Edward is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Edward who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more materials to be used in the stone quarrying business.

loans.name: Amooti

texts.en:
Amooti is 56 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala East region of Uganda. He is married and has five children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past 12 years, Amooti has been working hard to manage his small tailoring business. 

To help expand his business, Amooti has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more materials for making clothes for resale. This will help Amooti to generate greater profits so he can manage to pay his children's school fees. Amooti hopes that in the future he will be able to build a tailoring training center. 

Amooti is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Amooti who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more materials for making clothes for resale.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is 29 years old and lives in the town of Kubuli, in the Kampala south region of Uganda. For the past 4 years, Hellen has been working hard to manage her small restaurant, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Hellen has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more fresh food, like matooke, to cook and sell. It will help Hellen to generate greater profits and to pay for her medical expenses. Hellen hopes that, in the future, she will be able to start up another restaurant. 

Hellen is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs, like Hellen, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to stock more fresh food, like matooke, to cook and sell.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata, aged 28, is married and has two children aged 10 and 6. She has one additional dependant who lives with her as her sales assistant.  In 2001, Fatmata established her business selling limes and yams. She began her business because she wanted to help her husband in taking care of their home. Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 700,000 every month. 

Fatmata would like a loan of Le 3,000,000. She requires a loan in order to plough funds into her present business so that she can increase customers and profit. In the future, Fatmata plans for further expansion and to increase her stock, to earn more profits and to send her children to university.

She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To plough funds into her present business to increase her customers and profit.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more rice by the bag for her shop

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 48 years old. He lives in the small village of Terjola District with his family: wife, Julieta, his mother, who is a pensioner and two children (10 and 12 years old). Both of the children study in the village school. 

David and Julieta earn their living through agricultural business. They have 2 milk cows, a calf and a pig. They produce cheese and sell it at the local open market. The family owns a vineyard as well and they have 800 nut trees. Harvested products are sold at the local open market. The total average monthly income of the family is 550 Laris.

David has requested a loan to purchase a milking cow. He wants to expand his business. With three milk cows, they will be able to produce more cheese and other dairy food. This will increase the income of the family. With increased income they will be able to reinvest in the family's agricultural business to expand it and make it more profitable. Taking into account the above mentioned, the living conditions of the family will be improved.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow.

loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en:
This is 33 yr old Abibatu. She is married and has 2 children, aged 18 and 16yrs. In 1997, Abibatu established her Local Food Stuff business. She began her business because she wants to develop her family in a responsible manner by assisting her husband to solving some domestic problems. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about SLL 600,000 every month from this business. 

Abibatu would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,0000. Abibatu requires a loan in order to buy more local food stuff for the store so that customers will be attended to when needed. In the future, Abibatu plans to assist her husband to build a house and to give a quality education to her children so that they can take care of her during her old age.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more local food stuff for the store so that customers will be attended to when needed.

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
Robinah lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children, all of  whom are in school. She is not looking after any additional family members.

Robinah has been selling snacks for the last year from home and sells at retail, working six days a week. She does not have any other source of income.
She has requested a loan of UGX 200,000 from MCDT to enable her to purchase ingredients like cooking oil, wheat, cassava flour and charcoal in bulk. Her major challenges include the high transport costs of goods. She joined MCDT because she wanted more capital for her business. Her dream is to expand her business. She lives in her husband`s house with access to electricity, but no piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: to buy more cooking oil, wheat and cassava flour and charcoal.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 45 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli, in the Kampala south region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children. For the past 6 years, Mary has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential commodities like sugar and salt for resale, and will help Mary to generate greater profits and improve her standard of living. Mary hopes that, in the future, she will be able to start up another retail shop. 

Mary is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mary who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more essential commodities like sugar and salt to resell.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed is 39 years old and lives in the town of Mpigi in the Kampala North region of Uganda. He is married and has seven children who are all currently in school. For the past seven years, Mohamed has been working hard to manage his small business which sells electronic items like energy saver bulbs. 

To help expand his business, Mohamed has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more electrical items like bulbs for resale, and will help Mohamed to generate greater profits so he can pay his children's school fees. Mohamed hopes that in the future he will be able to build more rental houses. 

Mohamed is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mohamed who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy electrical items like bulbs for resale.

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en:
This is 50 yr old Kadiatu. She is married, and has 4 children aged 30, 27, 20 and 15yrs. She has 2 additional dependents who live with her as assistant sales men. 

In 1997, Kadiatu established her charcoal and wood business. She began her business because she was not educated so, therefore, she had to find an alternative way to generate income for the home and not to be dependent on her husband. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about SLL 500,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,000  in order to buy 10 piles of wood @ SLL 250,000, 45 bags of charcoal @ SLL10,000 and the balance will be use for transportation. She plans to build her own house and to improve on the business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy 10 piles of wood @ SLL 250,000, 45 bags of char-coal @ SLL10,000 and the balance will be use for transportation.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a new glass cutter.

loans.name: Mabinty

texts.en: This is 50 yr old Mabinty. She is a widow and has 2 children, aged 20 and 15 yrs. In 1997, Mabinty established her vegetable business. She began her business because she wanted to sustain the home, since she is now the bread winner. Working 7 days a week and 10 hrs a day, she earns about SLL 900, 000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,000. Mabinty requires a loan to buy more stock. In the future, Mabinty plans to build her own house. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more stock.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past 10 years, Simon has been working hard to sell livestock including cattle, sheep and goats. 

To help expand his business, Simon has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to to buy more livestock, and will help Simon to generate greater profits and to increase his daily stock. Simon hopes that in the future he will be able to to set up a dairy farm. 

Simon is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Simon who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more livestock

loans.name: Fayia

texts.en: This is 28 year old Fayia. He is married, and has 1 child, aged 3 years. In 2007, Fayia established his cosmetic business. He began his business because he wanted to improve on his life and the lives of his family. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about SLL 600,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of SLL 4,000,000. Fayia requires a loan in order to buy the latest items that customers are requesting. In the future, Fayia plans to expand the business by opening an outlet and he also plans to build a house for him and his family. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy the latest items that customers are requesting.

loans.name: Uma

texts.en:
Uma is 23 years old. She is married and has one child, aged 6.  In 2000, she established her grocery store business. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy grocery goods for her business.  

In the future, Uma plans to uplift the economic conditions of her family. She thanks you for your support.

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and their profit margains. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

loans.use: to buys grocery goods.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
This is 33 year old Ibrahim. He is married, and has no children. He has 1 additional dependent who lives with him as a sales assistant.  

In 2007, Ibrahim established his soft, alcoholic and energy drinks business. He began his business because he wanted to keep up his family. Working 7 days a week and 11 hrs. a day, he earns about SLL 600,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Ibrahim requires a loan in order to increase his stock and start selling by wholesale. In the future, Ibrahim plans to become a distributor for all the drinks companies in Sierra Leone. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to increase his stock and start selling by wholesale.

loans.name: Yosada

texts.en:
Yosada is 28 years-old. She is married and has one child, aged 6. In 2006, Yosada established her tailoring business. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy raw materials for her tailoring business.  

In the future, Yosada plans to uplift the economic conditions of her family. She thanks you for your support.

In the Kathmandu Valley, clothing is made to order. Tailor stalls line the streets where store owners sell material and work their sewing machines. These skilled tailors make school uniforms for children as well as the the traditional women's kurta surwal and men's daura surwal. With a Kiva loan, BPW borrowers are able to purchase additional cloth material or sewing machines that will increase production and profitability.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her business.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school.  Moses has been working hard to manage his brick-making business where he makes and sells bricks. 

To help expand his business, Moses has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to to buy firewood for burning raw bricks, and will help Moses to generate greater profits and to expand his business. Moses hopes that in the future he will be able to own a hardware store. 

Moses is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Moses who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy firewood for burning raw bricks

loans.name: Herman

texts.en:
Herman is 45 years old and lives in the town of Mpigi in the Kampala North region of Uganda. He is married and has seven children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past five years, Herman has been working hard to manage his retail shop which sells sugar and soap. 

To help expand his business, Herman has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential commodities like sugar and salt for resale, and will help Herman to generate greater profits and to pay his children's school fees. Herman hopes that in the future he will be able to build more rental houses. 

Herman is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Herman who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy essential commodities like sugar and salt for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to stock her shop with different categories of plastic rubbers and set pans.

loans.name: Tina

texts.en:
Tina is 37 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is single and has six children, four of whom are currently in school. For the past three years, Tina has been working hard to sell bananas. 

To help expand her business, Tina has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to to buy more bananas, and will help Tina to generate greater profits which will be used to pay school fees. Tina hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a retail shop. 

Tina is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Tina who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more bananas

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en:
This is 37 year old Amiinata. She is married, and has 1 child, aged 10 years. In 2006, Amiinata established her jeans, bedwear, slippers, shopping bags etc. business. She began her business because she wanted to assist her husband in up keep of their family. 

Working 7 days a week and 10 hrs a day, she earns about SLL 1,000,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 4,500,000. Amiinata requires a loan in order to buy fashionable jeans and shopping bags to attract customers. In the future, Aminata plans to educate her son up to university level and to also help her husband to build a house and operate another outlet. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy fashionable jeans and shopping bags to attract customers.

loans.name: Nato

texts.en:
Nato is 69 years old: she lives in the small village of Terjola District with her husband, Zhironi, and her 20-year-old grandson. Nato and Zhironi are pensioners and earn their living through an agricultural business. Their grandson, Rati, helps them in the agricultural activities. The family owns two milking cows, a bull and a calf.  They produce cheese every day which is sold at the local open market. The family owns a vineyard as well. They pick grapes in late summer and press wine which they sell in nearby villages. The total average monthly income of the family is 500 Lari.

Nato has requested a loan to purchase a milking cow. The family will be able to produce and sell more dairy food: cheese, curds and yogurt. They want to expand their business in order to earn a good profit. With increased profits, they will be able to reinvest in the family agricultural business, as well as spending more on the family's daily needs. As a result of these activities, the family's living conditions will be improved.

loans.use: to purchase a milking cow

loans.name: Yainkain

texts.en: This is 48 year old Yankain. She is married, and has 1 child, aged 6 months. In 1999, Yankain established her local food stuff and wearing business. She began her business to get income and to support her family. Working 7 days a week and 10 hrs a day, she earns about SLL 1,500,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Yankain has already received and successfully repaid her first loan, and now requires a new loan in order to buy more stock so that she can compete with colleague business partners. In the future, Yankain plans to build her own house and give a quality education to her adopted child. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more stock so that she can compete with colleague business partners.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: This is 38 year old Regina.  She is married and has 4 children, aged 21, 14, 13 and 10yrs. In 1995, Regina established her Palm Oil  and Charcoal business. She began her business because she wanted to be self-reliant and, moreover, to assist her husband in taking care of the family. Working 7 days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about SLL 800,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,000. She requires a loan in order to buy more gallons of palm oil and more bags of coal to satisfiy the customers' requests. In the future, she plans to help her husband to build their own house and improve on the business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more gallons of palm oil and more bags of coal to always satisfy customers' requests.

loans.name: Geghetsik

texts.en:
Geghetsik is from the village of Atskuri, in the Southern part of Georgia. She is 49 years old and lives with her 29 year old son and father in law (85 years old). Geghetsik has requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for her agricultural business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time, because of low income and her family’s poor living conditions. 

Geghetsik has 2 milk cows. She produces cheese and sells it in the village. She sells the harvest to local dairy products wholesalers. Ther total average monthly income of the family is 350 Laris. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Geghetsik has requested credit for start-up of a new agricultural business. Her loan request was approved in the frames of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions for the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the requested credit, Geghetsik will purchase up to 30 calfs. She will place them in a family-owned cattle-shed and feed them during summer and fall months. In winter, Geghetsik will sell the grown calfs for a higher price and get profit. She will use the received profit for purchasing additional milk cows for the expansion of the family farm. Also, Geghetsik will use the profits for improving the family's living conditions. As a result of the new business initiative implemented with the assistance of Kiva, the family will get more income and will be able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase calfs.

loans.name: Eka

texts.en:
Eka is from village Tkhiltskaro, Southern part of Georgia. She is 32 years old and lives with her husband Gogita and three children: a 5 year old son, and two daughters (1 and 2 years old). Eka and Gogita requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for agricultural business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of the income for the family is Gogita’s salary. He works as shepherd in the village and gets 150 Laris per month. It is hardly enough on food for 3 children. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the vulnerable poor category. 

Eka has requested a Credo loan for the start-up of an agricultural business. Her loan request was approved in the frames of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions for the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

Eka will place the purchased calves in an old cattle-shed located in the family yard. She will raise them and, after 12 months, will start milking them. Eka will start production of cheese and she will sell it at the open market of the nearby town. As a result of the new business initiative, implemented with the assistance of Kiva, the income of the family will increase by 200%. Eka and Gogita will be able to create better living conditions for their children and themselves.

loans.use: to purchase calves for the start-up of a dairy farm.

loans.name: Ketevan

texts.en:
Ketevan is 40 years old from the village of Lesa, in the district of Lanchkhuti. She is married and lives with her husband, Zurab, their 5-year-old daughter and her mother-in-law, who is a pensioner. Zurab works in construction and earns income for the family. According to the government's estimation, the family belongs to the vulnerable poor category and they receive monthly social assistance. Ketevan is busy with agricultural activities. She has a milking cow. She produces cheese and sells it with the milk at the local open market. The family owns a plot of land, where maize and nut-trees are grown. Harvested products are sold locally to retailers. The total average monthly income of the family is approximately 400 Lari.

With the requested credit, Ketevan plans to purchase an additional milking cow. She will get more milk and produce more cheese. This will increase sales and accordingly the family's income. With increased income, she will be able to reinvest in the family agricultural business in order to expand it and make it more profitable. Taking into account the above mentioned, the family's living conditions will be improved.

loans.use: to purchase a milking cow

loans.name: Chucuxcabel Group

texts.en:
In the community of Patachaj, San Cristóbal Totonicapán, Guatemala, in December of 2011, a group of 13 entrepreneurial women decided to form the Chucuxcabel Trust Bank, which is now about to begin its second loan cycle. Most of the women in the Chucuxabel Trust Bank are engaged in animal husbandry, weaving, embroidery and garment making, among other activities.

One of the 13 women in this Trust Bank is Santos, a 33-year old mother of three (two boys and one girl). While Santos herself was never able to attend school, she is happy to share that two of her children are already in primary school, which makes her very proud. In addition to running a small weaving business, Santos is currently engaged in animal husbandry. 

With her first loan from Friendship Bridge, Santos began raising pigs. She started small, with only one pig, which she eventually sold for money that she put towards her children's education. Thanks to this first loan, Santos was also able to save some money, which she plans to combine with her second loan from Friendship Bridge to buy three more pigs, as well as thread for her weaving. Before Friendship Bridge, Santos had been unable to receive loans from formal banks, due to of her lack of education. This severely limited her ability to run a successful business. Now, thanks to Friendship Bridge, Santos has access to working capital and is thankful for the opportunity to overcome her difficult situation. 

Santos's dream is to see her business grow and provide more money for her family. She wants to, one day, have a bigger farm and build her own home (as she is currently renting). Santos meets with her Trust Bank once a month for training, where they participate in educational lessons on business, money management, self-esteem, women’s rights, health and how to support their children’s education. These lessons, combined with their loans, help them to provide a better life for themselves and their families. The women of Chucuxcabel are grateful for the people who trust in them, enabling them to obtain loans for their businesses and overcome the poverty that surrounds them.

loans.use: to buy 3 pigs, and thread for weaving.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
58 year old Leonora is a resident of Talibon, Bohol. She is married and has six grown children. Leonora operates a sari-sari where she sell basic household needs like noodles, canned goods, soft drinks, seasoning, toiletries and rice. In addition to this, she is also a vegetable vendor. In her stall, she sells taro, bottle gourds, potatoes and green leafy vegetables. 

Leonora is asking for a loan to buy more vegetables and different merchandise for her store. Leonora hopes that with additional capital, she can continue to make better profit out of her business.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables and different merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Ma. Ailyn

texts.en:
Ma. Ailyn is a food vendor from the town of Talibon, Bohol. She sells snack foods like banana cue (deep fried banana) and home cooked dishes for meals for an income.  Her husband helps to support the family through fishing. She is 35 years old and has four children. Her eldest is 7 years old and the youngest is 10 months. 

She is asking for a loan to buy more ingredients like rice, meat and seasoning for her food business. She would like to continue improving her business so that she can give her family a comfortable life and her children can always go to school.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients like rice, meat and seasoning for her food business.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is 42 years old from the town of Talibon, Bohol. She is married with five children of ages 5, 8, 10, 12 and 16. She and her family are engaged in the fishing business for an income.  Her business has been in existence for 15 years now. She is asking for a loan to buy fishing materials like gasoline and crab traps. She is determined to make sure that her children has a good education with her income. She would like to continue her business so she can provide for her children's needs.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials like gasoline and crab traps

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en: Esterlita is from Calabayan, Ozamiz City. She is 54 years old, married and has 4 children. Esterlita owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for sale. Esterlita has been engaged in her business for 20 years and earns 20,000 PHP a month from it. In 2007, Esterlita joined GDMPC. Esterlita is requesting a loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Vision Group

texts.en:
In the hills of San Francisco el Alto, Totonicapán, Guatemala, where many people are engaged in clothing production, animal husbandry, and weaving, lives María and her family. María is a 30-year old married mother of two. Although María was only able to attend school through sixth grade, she now has high hopes for the future of her children. 

For many years María and her husband have run a small business making garments. It was not until three years ago that María realized that, in order for her business to continue to grow, she would need additional funding. As her clients’ demands for her product increased, María knew she would need to buy more raw materials than she could currently afford. As María explains, "we must seize the opportunities presented to us and not ignore them, because they only come once."  It was at this point that María decided to join Friendship Bridge’s Microcredit Plus program. 

María recruited other women in her community to join with her and founded the Vision Trust Bank. María is very happy and proud of herself and her fellow Trust Bank members for having the courage to take out loans and invest in their businesses. María’s loan has ensured that she and her husband always have the necessary materials on hand to produce what their clients order. María's greatest achievement has been to provide employment for three more people (one woman and two men), meaning her microloan not only impacts her and her family but also her community.

With this new loan, María plans to buy different types of fabrics and thread to diversify the products that she can produce. She currently delivers 25-30 orders of garments to her suppliers twice a month. María’s Trust Bank is about to begin its fifth loan cycle, providing nine women with funds that will help them develop their businesses. In addition to receiving loans, these women meet once a month to receive training from Friendship Bridge and to discuss topics such as business management, budgeting, self-esteem and health. These lessons not only provide the women with valuable information regarding their businesses and their family’s health, but also foster a community of support among the women.

loans.use: to buy different fabrics and thread.

loans.name: Izolda

texts.en:
Izolda is 48 years old. She is from the village of Orgora and lives there with her family: her husband, Arsen, and three daughters (aged 14, 20 and 21). The youngest is a schoolgirl and studies at the village school, the 20-year-old daughter is a university entrant and the eldest is a student. Izolda and Arsen run an agricultural business. 

The only source of income for the family is a small dairy farm with two milking cows. They produce dairy products: cheese, curds and yogurt. Part of the dairy food is used by the family and the rest is sold at the local open market. The total average monthly income of the family is 500 Lari. They don’t have enough income to save enough to finance the studies of their three children. Their income is hardly enough to provide food for a five-member family. 

With the requested credit, Izolda will buy calves and raise them. She plans to sell them after a year for a higher price. She hopes to receive a good profit. This will positively influence the family's income. Izolda will be able to finance her children's education and make them happy.

Izolda and Arsen hope for your help and kindness.

loans.use: to purchase calves to raise and sell

loans.name: Juditha

texts.en: Juditha is from Kinangay Sur, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 68 years old, widowed and has five children. To make a living, Juditha owns and operates a business retail store. Juditha has been engaged in her business for 7 years and earns 10,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2003, Juditha joined GDMPC. Juditha is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps, etc. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps, etc.

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en: Marjorie is 27 years old from Talibon, Bohol. She is married with 2 children, ages 3 and 4. Marjorie finds her livelihood through fishing with her husband and buying and selling sea cucumbers. She is asking for a loan to buy more sea cucumbers from other fishermen that she can resell for a profit. Her income will then be used to provide her children with a healthy diet and to further reinvest in the business.

loans.use: to buy more sea cucumbers

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 34 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is widowed and has two children who are both currently in school. For the past four years, Joyce has been working hard to manage her retail business selling charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Joyce has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to to buy more charcoal, and will help Joyce to generate greater profits which will be used to pay school fees. Joyce hopes that in the future she will be able to to open a bar. 

Joyce is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Joyce who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Goderdzi

texts.en:
Goderdzi is 46 years old. He lives in a small village in Zestaponi District with his family: his wife, Lela, and two children (aged 14 and 15). Both of their children go to the local school. 

Goderdzi and Lela earn their living through an agricultural business. In particular, they have livestock with four cows, a calf, two bulls and two pigs. They are very hard-working people who take good care of their livestock. They milk their cows twice a day and produce dairy food: cheese, curds and yogurt. They sell the dairy foods that they produce in nearby villages. The family also owns 0.9 hectare of land, where nut-trees are grown. They sell the nuts in the Zestaponi market. In addition to his agricultural business, Goderdzi works in construction and earns additional income for the family. The total average monthly income of the family is 600 Lari.  

Goderdzi has requested a loan to purchase a milking cow so he can expand his dairy farm. With five milking cows, Goderdzi and Lela will be able to get more milk and produce more dairy foods. This will increase the sales from their business. With increased profits, they will be able to reinvest in the family's agricultural business.

loans.use: to purchase a milking cow

loans.name: Josejhane

texts.en: Josejhane is 30 years old from Talibon, Bohol. She is married with one child, a son who is 5 years old. She is currently engaged in food vending and tricycle transportation services. This business has been in operation for 4 years now. She is asking for a loan to buy tools and tires and to pay for vulcanization. She is motivated to work hard and earn more so she can provide for her child and support his education.

loans.use: to buy tools and tires and to pay for vulcanization

loans.name: Guram

texts.en:
Guram is 56 years old. He is from the Terjola District, is married and lives with his wife, Lia, and their 24-year-old son, Gogi. Gogi is a probationer at the aviation institute. Guram and Lia run an agricultural business. They have a vineyard with 1000 grapevines. They also are busy with cattle breeding: they have five milking cows, a calf and a pig. Gogi and Lia milk the cows twice a day and produce cheese. They sell harvested grapes and produce cheese for the local open market. The total average monthly income of the family is 500 Lari. 

Guram has requested a loan to purchase a milking cow as he wants to expand his dairy farm. Guram and Lia will be able to sell on average 100 kg of cheese per month at the local open market. This will increase the family's income. With increased profits, they will be able to reinvest in the family agricultural business to expand it and make it more profitable. Also, the family members will be able to increase their spending to satisfy their daily needs and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a milking cow

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en: Rosalyn is married with two children. Rosalyn is 25 years old and resides in Montol, Ozamis City, Philippines. Rosalyn owns and operates a farm, planting and harvesting root crops for sale to earn a living, and she's been in this business for five years. Each month, she earns 3,000 PHP doing this type of work. She requested a loan of 3,500 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. In 2010, Rosalyn joined GDMPC. Rosalyn wants to make improvements to her house and to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Hanifa

texts.en:
Hanifa is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is single and has four children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past 10 years, Hanifa has been working hard to manage her business selling tomatoes and Irish potatoes. 

To help expand her business, Hanifa has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to to buy more Irish potatoes, and will help Hanifa to generate greater profits which will be used to pay school fees. Hanifa hopes that in the future she will be able to to own a grocery. 

Hanifa is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hanifa who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more Irish potatoes

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is from Silanga, Tangub City. She is 44 years old. Helen is married and has three children. To make a living, Helen owns and operates a business venture in the service sector operating transportation. Helen been in her business for twelve years and earns 3,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2010, Helen joined GDMPC. Helen is requesting a loan of 5,200 PHP which will be used to repair her existing vehicle for better service. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to repair her existing vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en: 43-year-old Merlinda lives in Talibon with her family. She is married with four children, two of them still dependents. She has a thriving hog-raising business which helps her raise her family. This business started ten years ago. Merlinda is asking for a loan to buy feed and pay for her children's tuition fees. She plans to continue investing in hog-raising and make the business even bigger to better her family's future.

loans.use: to buy feed and pay for tuition fees

loans.name: Las Amigas Group

texts.es:
El comité se llama “Las Amigas”  ya que todas  dependen unas de otra para que su comité salga adelante y las integrantes están para ayudarse y seguir progresando en sus actividades.
Margarita es la presidenta del grupo, y ella misma se define como una persona muy trabajadora y por sobre todo muy emprendedora.  Comenta que se dedica a la venta de librería desde hace un tiempo, por lo que tiene ya una buena clientela que siempre acude a comprar de ella los útiles que vende.
Solicita el crédito para la compra de cuadernos, libros, lápices, borradores, pinceles y demás insumos para poder seguir surtiendo a sus clientes.
texts.en: The group is called "Las Amigas" because all of the members depend on each other to make headway, and the members are doing that by helping one another and making progress with their activities. Margarita is the group's president, and she defines herself as a very hard worker and above all a very enterprising woman. She has made a living running a bookstore for some time, and she has a good customer base that is always coming by to purchase the items she sells. She is requesting the loan to purchase notebooks, books, pencils, erasers, brushes and other supplies to keep her business stocked for her customers.

loans.use: to purchase notebooks, books, pencils, erasers, brushes and other items.

loans.name: Melati Group

texts.en:
Pictured is the Melati group, neighbors in the same village in Melaya, West Bali (three members of the group are not in the photo because of a religious ceremony they were attending at the temple). The group was formed out of these women’s common interest in raising pigs to supplement family income, and out of their interest in education on the best practices for pig raising. 

The group has requested a new loan of 19,500,000 IDR, its fourth from MUK. Each member will receive 1,300,000 IDR which will be used to buy two quality piglets plus pig feed. While the price of feed and piglets is expensive, members of the group are already feeling the benefits from their first loan through their ability to meet the needs of their families. 

Group member Ni Ketut will use her portion of the loan to buy a pig to breed. She has seen the possibilities in selling piglets. To reduce costs, she gave the mixture feed (feed mixture is a mixture of good quality feed which's purchase at store that is mixed with various types of leaves, such as banana leaves, taro leaves and other leaf types are useful for the growth of pigs). She hopes her pig venture will succeed and bring prosperity to the whole family.

loans.use: to buy a pig to breed.

loans.name: Rolina

texts.en: Rolina is 32 years old from the community of Talibon, Bohol. She is married with six children. Her eldest is thirteen years old and her youngest is two years old. Rolina’s desire is to help her husband in their fishing business. She is asking for a loan to buy flashlights, batteries and gasoline for their boat. Rolina would like to make sure that she can make her business more profitable. Her income will assure her that her children are kept in school and her family is well-nourished.

loans.use: to buy flashlights, batteries and gasoline

loans.name: Herberth Mauricio

texts.es:
Herbert, está solicitando un nuevo préstamo para mejorar el negocio, siguiendo la inversión anterior, se comprara el juego de las cuatro llantas, para el taxi, este préstamo le ayudara a mejorar las condiciones del vehículo y seguir brindando un servicio más seguro a los clientes.  
Con el préstamo anterior pudo reparar el vehículo con la compra de repuestos, hasta el momento no ha tenido inconvenientes,  solo espera que este préstamo tambien le ayude a realizar una buena inversión y seguir trabajando para su familia.
texts.en: Herbert is requesting a new loan in order to improve his business following his previous investment. He plans to purchase a set of four tires for his taxi. This loan will help improve his vehicle's conditions and provide a safer service for his customers. With the previous loan he was able to repair the vehicle by purchasing replacement parts, and he hasn't had any inconveniences up to the moment. He hopes that this loan will also help him make a good investment so he can keep working for his family.

loans.use: to purchase a set of four tires for his taxi.

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia is 47 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has six children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past four years, Sylvia has been working hard to manage her retail shop which sells sugar, soap and salt. 

To help expand her business, Sylvia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy essential commodities like sugar and salt for resale, and will help Sylvia to generate greater profits and pay her child's school fees. Sylvia hopes that in the future she will be able to open a boutique business. 

Sylvia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sylvia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy essential commodities like sugar and salt for resale

loans.name: Nelson Cesar

texts.es:
Nelson es un joven de 23 años de edad, muy trabajador y entusiasta vive en el distrito de Parcona, Ica Perú, el cual se caracteriza por su clima cálido y acogedor, así como también se desarrolla la agricultura en especial los cultivos de esparrago, uva, algodón, entre otros, podemos encontrar en este distrito el bosque de piedras el cual se caracteriza por tener formaciones rocosas en forma de animales, personas, entre otros.  A Nelson le gusta jugar futbol con sus amigos de su barrio y también le gusta degustar uno de sus platillos favoritos el cual son los riquísimos “Tallarines Rojos”. Debido a los pocos recursos económicos de sus padres el solo pudo estudiar hasta el quinto grado de educación secundaria, pero le hubiera gustado estudiar la carrera de administración.

Día a día Nelson trabaja como chofer de mototaxi, ya que con  este trabajo el puede apoyar en su casa con los gastos,   el trabaja alrededor de 10 horas al día y puede atender hasta 30 clientes diariamente, el cree que le va bien en su negocio porque es muy responsable cuando conduce y sobre todo porque es muy amable con los clientes.

Nelson está muy agradecido con los prestatarios Kiva ya que gracias al gran apoyo que le han brindado el podrá reparar su vehículo de trabajo ya que consume mucha gasolina y aceite, realizara una bajada de motor y un mantenimiento general, con ello el tendrá un vehículo en buen estado y podrá trabajar mejor cada día y podrá seguir apoyando a su hogar en los gastos y seguirá luchando por hacer realidad su más grande sueño:” Tener su casa propia y tener una gran negocio”.
texts.en:
Nelson is 23 years old and is very hardworking and enthusiastic.  He lives in Parcona district in the province of Ica, Peru.  The district is known for its warm and welcoming climate as well as for the crops that are grown there, most notably asparagus, grapes, and cotton.  The district is also known for being the location of the ‘bosque de piedras’ [‘stone forest’], which contains rock formations that are shaped like animals, people, and other forms.  Nelson enjoys playing football with his friends from his neighborhood, and also likes sampling one of his favorite dishes, “Tallarines Rojos” [“red noodles”].  Nelson was only able to study up through his fifth year of secondary school due to his parents’ limited economic resources, but he would have liked to have pursued a career in administration.  

Nelson makes a living as a motorcycle taxi driver, which enables him to help his family with the household expenses.  He typically works about 10 hours a day, and can provide his services to as many as 30 customers in a day.  He believes that his business is going well because he drives very responsibly, and most importantly, because he is very pleasant to his customers.  

Nelson is very grateful to Kiva lenders, since their support will make it possible for him to repair his work vehicle.  His motorcycle taxi consumes a lot of gasoline and oil, and so he is going to tune up the engine and also do general maintenance work.  These repairs will ensure that Nelson has a vehicle that is in good condition and works better, and that he can continue helping his family with the household expenses and keep working toward achieving his greatest dream: to have his own house and own a large business.

loans.use: to do general maintenance work on his motorcycle taxi and get an engine tune-up.

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 27 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past eight years, Martin has been working hard to manage his small business which sells sand that is used for building houses. 

To help expand his business, Martin has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more sand to sell for building, and will help Martin to generate greater profits and pay his children's school fees. Martin hopes that in the future he will be able to own a hardware shop. 

Martin is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Martin who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more sand to sell for building.

loans.name: Marianela

texts.es:
Marianéla, necesita invertir en el negocio, ya que con el préstamo anterior logro mejorar las ganancias manteniéndose hasta el momento con lo necesario para continuar vendiendo, ella comprara pepinos, rábanos, tomates, cebolla, güisquiles, aguacates, y frutas frescas, esto le ayudara a seguir creciendo y ofrecer productos frescos.
Ella nos comenta que en su núcleo familiar ha nacido un nuevo miembro, el cual le llena de alegría, tambien manifiesta que ha tenido la aceptación de mas y nuevos clientes que le ayudan hasta el momento a mejorar las ganancias familiares.
texts.en:
Marianéla needs to invest in her business, as with the previous loan she managed to improve her earnings, supporting herself up to now, and having what she needs to continue selling. 

She will buy cucumbers, radishes, tomatoes, onions, pear squash, avocados and fresh fruit. This will help her to continue growing and offering fresh produce.

She tells us that a new member has been born into into her immediate family, which fills her with joy. She also states she is popular with new and more  customers, which up to now has helped her to improve the family earnings.

loans.use: To buy cucumbers, radishes, tomatoes, onions, pear squash, avocados and fresh fruit.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add to her small working capital so that she can serve customers who want to send larger amounts of money

loans.name: Safina

texts.en: Safina is 35 years old. She has three children aged between seven and fifteen. All of the children attend school. The loan requested will be used to buy sugar, and soap to sell. She plans to use the profits for savings.

loans.use: To buy more sugar and soap to sell.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 33 years old and married with three children. He sells various goods, such as lotions, soap, buns, water, sugar, etc. James has four years of experience in this work and he currently employs two people to help him.  The hours of his business are from 5 a.m to 10 p.m every day. 

James has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to buy various goods, such as lotions, soap, buns, water, sugar, etc., for resale.  With any profits, he will be able to save money for his future, pay school fees for his children, and reinvest in his business.

loans.use: to buy various goods, such as lotions, soap, buns, water, sugar, etc., for resale.

loans.name: Joel

texts.en: Joel is from Lam-an, Ozamiz City. He is 43 years old, married, and has three children. To make a living, Joel owns and operates a business venture in the services sector providing transportation services. Joel has been engaged in his business for five years and earns 10,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2007, Joel joined GDMPC. Joel is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to repair his existing vehicle to provide better service. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to repair his existing vehicle to provide better service.

loans.name: Maria Esther

texts.es:
María es una mujer de 46 años, vive en la ciudad de Chincha y se encuentra felizmente casada, ella tiene 4 hijos quienes 2 de ellos ya son mayores y los otros 2 aun se encuentran bajo su cuidado; María siempre ha sido una persona muy trabajadora y entusiasta, que ha dedicado todos sus esfuerzos junto con su esposo para sacar adelante a su familia; lamentablemente por la necesidad de trabajar y solventar sus gastos no pudo estudiar una carrera profesional, pero le hubiera gustado mucho poder hacerlo, en sus ratos libres le gusta ver noticieros y programas educativos en televisión y en algunas ocasiones cocina una riquísima Carapulcra con Sopa Seca para compartir con su familia.
 Por iniciativa propia y gracias al apoyo de su familia, desde hace unos meses María puso en marcha su pequeño negocio de venta de ropa, ella realiza sus ventas de manera ambulatoria ofreciendo sus productos por las calles y mercados de su ciudad, así también parte sus ventas lo realiza en su hogar; María trabaja un aproximado de 6 horas diarias, ella cree que su negocio marcha bien debido a su carisma y buena atención.
María se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestatarios Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la compra de mercadería, tales como: pantalones, polos largos, buzos, chompas, entre otras prendas; de esta manera María tendrá su negocio mejor abastecido y podrá incrementar sus ventas e ingresos económicos, con los cuales desea poder ahorrar el dinero suficiente para que juntamente con su esposo puedan comprar su casa propia.
texts.en:
